pli-tv-kd5:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.2_0: At that time King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha ruled over eighty thousand villages.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.3_0: And at Campā there was a prominent merchant who had a son called Soṇa Koḷivisa. He had been raised in great comfort
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.4_0: and even had hairs growing on the soles of his feet.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.5_0: On one occasion, because of some business, King Bimbisāra had the chiefs of those eighty thousand villages gathered. He then sent a message to Soṇa,
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.1_0: They had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; they had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.3_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.4_0: those with eyes might see what’s there—
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.5_0: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.6_0: We go for refuge to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.7_0: to the Teaching, and to the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.0_0: The going forth of the lay life to homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.2_0: “As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.3_0: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.4_0: When those eighty-four thousand chiefs had rejoiced and expressed their appreciation for the Buddha’s teaching, they got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with their right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.1_0: Soon after they had left, Soṇa approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.2_0: and told him what he had thought,
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.3_0: “Sir, as I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.4_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.5_0: Please give me the going forth.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.6_0: And Soṇa received the going forth and the full ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.7_0: Soon after his ordination, while staying in Cool Grove,
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.2_0: His walking-path was soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.3_0: Then, while he was in seclusion, he thought,
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.4_0: “I’m one of the Buddha’s energetic disciples,
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.5_0: But my mind is not freed from the defilements by not grasping.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.7_0: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.8_0: Perhaps I should return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.1_0: Just then the Buddha read Soṇa’s mind.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2_1: so too the Buddha appeared in Cool Grove,
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.3_0: Soon afterwards as the Buddha and a number of monks were walking about the dwellings, they came to Soṇa’s walking-path.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.4_0: The Buddha looked at it and asked the monks,
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.5_0: “Whose walking-path is this? It’s soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.6_0: And they told him what had happened.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.7_0: that walking-path was soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.11_0: “Think about it, Soṇa. When you were previously a householder, weren’t you a skilled lute player?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.13_0: “When the strings were too tight, was the lute melodious and easy to play?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.1_0: The Buddha then approached Soṇa’s dwelling and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.3_0: and the Buddha said to him,
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.4_0: “Soṇa, when you were in seclusion, didn’t you think,
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.5_0: ʻI’m one of the Buddha’s energetic disciples,
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.6_0: But my mind is not freed from the defilements by not grasping.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.8_0: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.9_0: Perhaps I should return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit’?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.1_0: “When the strings were too loose, was the lute melodious and easy to play?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.3_0: “But when the strings were neither too tight nor too loose, but set to a balanced tension, was the lute then melodious and easy to play?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.5_0: “Just so, Soṇa, too much energy leads to restlessness and too little to laziness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.1_0: So exert a balanced energy and discover an evenness of the spiritual faculties. And that is where you should take up the meditation object.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3_0: Then, as a strong man might bend or stretch out his arm, so too the Buddha disappeared from the presence of Soṇa in.
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3_1: In the same way, Soṇa vanished from Soṇakāyana appeared to Soṇa, while the Vulture Peak Mountain.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.1_0: After some time, Soṇa exerted a balanced energy, discovered an evenness of the spiritual faculties, and that is where he took up his meditation object.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.2_0: He then stayed by himself, secluded, heedful, energetic, and diligent. And in this very life, he soon realized with his own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.3_0: He understood that birth had come to an end, that the spiritual life had been lived, that the job had been done, that there was no further state of existence.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.4_0: And Venerable Soṇa became one of the perfected ones.
pli-tv-kd5:1.19.2_0: “Let me declare perfect insight in the presence of the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.19.3_0: He then went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:1.19.4_0: and told him what had happened,
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.2_0: “Soṇa, the king wishes to see your feet,
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.3_0: but don’t point your feet at the King.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.4_0: If you just sit down cross-legged in front of the King,
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.5_0: he’ll be able to see them.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.6_0: And they sent him away on a palanquin.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.7_0: Soṇa then approached King Bimbisāra, bowed, and sat down cross-legged in front of him.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.8_0: And the King saw the hairs growing on the soles of his feet.
pli-tv-kd5:1.20.1_0: “Venerable Sir, a monk who is a perfected one—who has ended the corruptions, lived the spiritual life, done the job, put down the burden, realized the true goal, cut the bond to existence, gained release by right insight—he is committed to six things:
pli-tv-kd5:1.20.2_0: to renunciation, seclusion, harmlessness, the end of grasping, the end of craving, and non-confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.21.2_0: ʻNo doubt this venerable is committed to renunciation because of confidence.’ But this is the wrong way to look at it.
pli-tv-kd5:1.21.3_0: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.2_0: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to seclusion because they enjoy possessions, honor, and popularity.’
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.3_0: But it should not be seen like this.
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.4_0: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.2_0: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to kindness because they believe that adhering to precepts and observances is the most important thing.’
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.3_0: But it should not be seen like this.
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.4_0: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.1_0: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.2_0: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.3_0: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.1_0: Sir, for a monk who is fully freed in this way, even if he sees compelling visual objects, his mind is not overpowered by them.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.2_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.3_0: Even if he hears compelling sounds,
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.7_0: and thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t occupy the mind.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.8_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.11_0: and thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t occupy the mind.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.12_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.1_0: It’s just like a granite mountain, a single solid mass without cracks. It doesn’t shake or tremble when powerful rainstorms arrive from any direction.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.2_0: violent storms were to come from the west,
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.4_0: They couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.5_0: The mind of the monk who is fully freed in this way is just like that.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.6_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.7_0: Even if he hears compelling sounds,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.10_0: who has cut off craving for continued existence,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.11_0: There is nothing more to add
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.12_0: And nothing that needs to be done.
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.13_0: Just as a single solid rock,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.15_0: So too, all visual objects, and sounds,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.17_0: And mental objects, good and bad,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.19_0: Their mind is steady and free
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.1_0: For the one committed to renunciation
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.20_0: And they observe it as it disappears.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.2_0: And to seclusion of the mind,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.3_0: For the one committed to harmlessness
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.4_0: And to the end of grasping,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.5_0: For the one committed to the end of craving
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.6_0: And to non-confusion of the mind,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.7_0: Having seen the arising of the senses,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.9_0: For the one who is fully freed,
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.0_0: The prohibition against sandals with double-layered soles, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.1_0: When the message had been delivered, the Buddha said to the monks,
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.2_0: “It’s in this way that someone from a good family declares perfect insight. The matter is spoken of, but the person isn’t mentioned.
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.3_0: And still some foolish men here seem to declare perfect insight just for fun. Afterward they experience distress because of that.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.3_0: I allow you to use sandals with single-layered soles.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.4_0: “When I went forth into homelessness, Sir, I left behind eighty cartloads of gold coins and a group of seven elephants.
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.5_0: If I were to walk around in sandals with single-layered soles, some people would say, ʻSoṇa left all this behind when he went forth
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.6_0: and now he’s attached to sandals with single-layered soles.’
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.1_0: Then, after instructing those eighty thousand chiefs in worldly matters, the King dismissed them, saying,
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.3_0: Now go and visit the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.4_0: He will instruct us about the afterlife.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.5_0: Those eighty thousand chiefs approached the Vulture Peak.
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.1_0: If you allow them to the Sangha of monks, I too will use them.
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.2_0: If not, I won’t use them either.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.3_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.5_0: But you should not wear sandals with double-layered soles,
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.1_0: There they approached Venerable Sāgata, who at that time was the Buddha’s attendant.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.3_0: “Venerable Sir, eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit you.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.5_0: “Well then, please wait here for a moment, while I announce you to the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.1_0: Then, while those eighty thousand chiefs were watching, he sunk into the stone slab he was standing on and emerged in front of the Buddha. And he said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.2_0: “Venerable Sir, eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit you.
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.4_0: “Well then, Sāgata, please prepare a seat in the shade of the dwelling.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.6.2_0: He took a stool, sunk down in front of the Buddha, and as those eighty thousand chiefs were watching, he once more emerged from that stone slab. He then prepared a seat in the shade of the dwelling,
pli-tv-kd5:1.6.3_0: and the Buddha came out and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.1_0: Those eighty thousand chiefs approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.2_0: But they were preoccupied with Sāgata, not with the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.3_0: After reading the minds of those eighty thousand chiefs, the Buddha said to Sāgata,
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.4_0: “Well then, Sāgata, show us more superhuman abilities, more wonders of supernormal power.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.5_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” he rose up into the air, walked back and forth in space, and he stood, sat down, and lay down there. He emitted smoke and fire, and then disappeared.
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.1_0: After this display of supernormal powers, he bowed down at the feet of the Buddha, and said,
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.4_0: That Blessed One is my Teacher,
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.6_0: Those eighty thousand chiefs thought, “It’s astonishing and amazing
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.7_0: that even a disciple should be so powerful and mighty. Imagine what the teacher must be like!” And now they paid attention to the Buddha, not to Sāgata.
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.1_0: Having read their minds, the Buddha gave those eighty thousand chiefs a progressive teaching:
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.2_0: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.3_0: When the Buddha knew that their minds were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.5_0: Just as a clean and stainless cloth takes the dye properly,
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.6_0: so too, while they were sitting right there, those eighty thousand chiefs experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.7_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.1_0: Soon afterwards a monk who was traveling through the Kosalan country on his way to visit the Buddha at Sāvatthī became sick.
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.2_0: He stepped off the path and sat down at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.3_0: People saw him and said to him,
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.4_0: they asked for where they went.
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.5_0: “I’ll go to Sāvatthī to visit the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.10_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.11_0: And you should not use any kind of skin.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.12_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.1_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned that bad monk:
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.2_0: “Is it true, monk, that you encouraged someone to kill?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.4_0: “Foolish man, how can you encourage someone to kill? Haven’t I in many ways criticized killing and praised the abstention from killing?
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.5_0: Foolish man, this won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.6_0: after criticizing them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.8_0: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.9_0: And you should not use cattle hide.
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.4_0: “Thanks, but the Buddha has prohibited us from traveling in vehicles.” And being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept.
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.5_0: After being released, that monk went to Sāvatthī, where he told the monks what had happened.
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.7_0: “I allow a vehicle when you’re sick.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.2_0: “A vehicle pulled by women or by men?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.4_0: “I allow a rickshaw pulled by men.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.5_0: Soon afterwards a certain monk was even more uncomfortable when jolted around in a vehicle.
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.6_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.7_0: “I allow a mattress without collection cloth.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.0_0: The prohibition against high and luxurious resting places.
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six used high and luxurious resting places, such as:
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.2_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a quilt filled with cotton down, a woolen rug decorated with the images of wild animals, a woolen rug with long fleece on one side, a woolen rug with long fleece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent rug made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a bed with a canopy, a bed with red cushions at each end.
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.3_0: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.4_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.5_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.5.1_0: “You should not use high and luxurious resting places, such as:
pli-tv-kd5:10.5.2_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a quilt filled with cotton down, a woolen rug decorated with the images of wild animals, a woolen rug with long fleece on one side, a woolen rug with long fleece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent sheet made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a bed with a canopy, or bed with red cushions at each end.
pli-tv-kd5:10.5.3_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.0_0: The prohibition against all kinds of voting tickets.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.1_0: When the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.2_0: the Buddha had prohibited high and luxurious resting places,
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.3_0: they used luxurious skins: lion skins, tiger skins, and leopard skins.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.4_0: They laid down on the beds and benches made upholstered with cotton down, outside the monastic boundary on the bed, and the bench were outside.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.5_0: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.6_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.7_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.8_0: “You should not use luxurious skins: lion skins, tiger skins, or leopard skins.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.1_0: When the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.2_0: the Buddha had prohibited luxurious skins,
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.4_0: They laid down on the beds and benches made upholstered with cotton down, outside the monastic boundary on the bed, and the bench were outside.
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.5_0: At this time a certain bad monk was associating with the family of a bad lay follower.
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.6_0: One morning that monk robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to that lay follower’s house, where he sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.7_0: That lay follower approached the monk, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.1_0: At that time that lay follower had a beautiful young calf with variegated hide, just like a young leopard.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.2_0: The bad monk stared at that calf
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.3_0: and the lay follower asked him why.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.4_0: “Sir, why are you stared at this calf?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.5_0: He replied, “I want the skin of that calf.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.6_0: The bad lay follower then slaughtered the calf, skinned it, and gave the skin to the bad monk.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.7_0: The monk hid the skin under his upper robe and left.
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.11_0: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.12_0: “How can a monk encourage someone to kill? Hasn’t the Buddha in many ways criticized killing and praised the abstention from killing?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.1_0: The mother-cow, longing for her calf, followed behind him.
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.2_0: When other monks asked him why,
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.3_0: why the cow was following him,
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.4_0: he replied he did not know.
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.5_0: But his upper robe was smeared with blood
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.6_0: When other monks asked him why,

pli-tv-kd5:10.9.9_0: they said, “So did you encourage someone to kill?”

pli-tv-kd5:11.1.1_0: At that time people’s beds and benches were upholstered and covered with skin.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.2_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit down.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.4_0: “I allow you to sit down on what belongs to a householder, but not to lie down on it.”
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.5_0: But then the dwellings were held together by straps of leather.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.6_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit down.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.7_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.8_0: “I allow you to sit down against a mere binding made of skin.”
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six entered the village wearing sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.5_0: “You should not enter the village wearing sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.7_0: Soon afterwards a certain sick monk was not able to enter the village without his sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.8_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.9_0: “I allow sick monks to enter the village while wearing sandals.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.0_0: The account of the building hut and the site of the hut.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in Avantī on Papataka Hill at Kuraraghara.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.2_0: And the layman Soṇa of the pointy ears was Mahākaccānas attendant.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.3_0: On one occasion Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.5_0: “Venerable, the way I understand your teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.6_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.7_0: “May Venerable Mahākaccāna please give me the going forth!”
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.1_0: “Why did it take you so long to go forth?”
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.2_0: “I have long seen the danger in worldly pleasures. Still, because household life is crowded and very busy, I was not able to leave.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.3_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.4_0: “Having seen the danger in the world,
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.6_0: The noble one doesn’t delight in what’s bad;
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.7_0: In the bad, the pure one doesn’t delight.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.10_0: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.

pli-tv-kd5:13.11.20_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.21_0: “In the southern region of Avantī there are few monks.

pli-tv-kd5:13.11.2_0: “The Buddha approves of me. This is the time to bring up what my preceptor said.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.3_0: He got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, bowed down at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.4_0: “Sir, my preceptor, Venerable Mahākaccāna, pays respect with his head at the Buddha’s feet.” He then repeated everything Mahākaccāna had asked him to say.

pli-tv-kd5:13.12.1_0: In this regard, the following are the outlying countries:
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.2_0: In the eastern direction there is a town called _Gajaṅgala_, with another town called _Mahāsālā_ on the other side of it. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.3_0: In the south-eastern direction there is a river called _Sallavatī_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.4_0: In the southern direction there is a town called _Setakaṇṇika_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.5_0: In the western direction there is a brahmin village called _Thūṇa_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.6_0: In the northern direction there is a mountain called _Usīraddhaja_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.

pli-tv-kd5:13.2.11_0: At that time in the southern region of Avantī, there were few monks.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.12_0: Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was Mahākaccāna able to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give the full ordination to Venerable Soṇa.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.1_0: “It’s difficult, Soṇa, to live the spiritual life all one’s life, eating one meal a day and sleeping by oneself.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.2_0: So follow the instruction of the Buddhas while remaining as a householder, and at suitable times you may eat one meal a day, sleep by yourself, and practice celibacy.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.3_0: As a result, Soṇa’s intention to go forth died down.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.4_0: A second time Soṇa asked Mahākaccāna for the going forth, but got the same response.

pli-tv-kd5:13.2.8_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.9_0: “May Venerable Mahākaccāna please give me the going forth!”
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.0_0: for Mahākaccāna’s complexion with tubers, not for the five points.
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.1_0: When he had completed the rainy-season residence, he thought,
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.2_0: “I’ve heard that the Buddha is like this and like that, but I haven’t seen this for myself. If my preceptor allows me, I shall go and visit the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.3_0: When he had come out from seclusion, Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:13.4.2_0: “Venerable Sir, while I was in seclusion I reflected that
pli-tv-kd5:13.4.3_0: ‘I’ve heard that the Buddha is like this and like that, but I haven’t seen this for myself. If my preceptor allows me, I shall go and visit the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One.’
pli-tv-kd5:13.4.4_0: I’d allow him to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, allow me.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.4.6_0: Please go and visit the Buddha, the perfected and fully awakened one.
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.1_0: You will see him—pleasing to the eye and inspiring confidence; peaceful in mind and faculties; attained to the supreme subduing and calm; tamed, guarded, and restrained in his sense faculties; a great being.
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.2_0: Then, Soṇa, in my name, pay respect with your head at the Buddha’s feet and say, ʻ
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.3_0: Venerable Sir, my preceptor, Venerable Mahākaccāna, pays respect with his head at the Buddha’s feet.’
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.5_0: ʻIn the southern region of Avantī, Sir, there are few monks. Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was it possible to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give me the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.6_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow a smaller group of monks to give the full ordination in Avantī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.1_0: In Avantī the ground is dark and hard, made rough by the hooves of cattle.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.2_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sandals with multi-layered soles in Avantī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.3_0: In Avantī people value bathing and cleanliness.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.4_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow unrestricted bathing in Avantī.

pli-tv-kd5:13.6.6_0: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.

pli-tv-kd5:13.7.1_0: At present people give robes to monks who are outside the monastic boundary, saying,

pli-tv-kd5:13.7.4_0: “Such-and-such people have given you a robe.” But being afraid of wrongdoing, they don’t accept, thinking,
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.5_0: “We might commit an offense entailing relinquishment.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.6_0: Perhaps the Buddha will point out a way to deal with robes.’”
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.8_0: He got up from his seat, bowed down, and circumambulated Mahākāccāna with his right side toward him. He then put his dwelling in order, took his bowl and robe, and set out for Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.1_0: When he eventually arrived, he went to the Buddha in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery. He bowed to the Buddha, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.3_0: “Ānanda, please prepare a resting place for this newly arrived monk.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.5_0: “When the Buddha says this, it means he wishes to stay in the same dwelling as Venerable Soṇa.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.6_0: and he was staying in that dwelling.
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.10_0: How long have you been a monk?”
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.1_0: Then, after spending much of the night outside, the Buddha entered the dwelling,
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.3_0: Rising early in the morning, the Buddha said to Soṇa,
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.5_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” he chanted the entire Chapter of Eights.
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.6_0: When he was finished, the Buddha said,
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.8_0: You have learned the Chapter Eights well; you have remembered it well.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.0_0: The prohibition against what is entirely blue, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.10_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.11_0: “You should not wear sandals that are entirely blue,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.12_0: entirely yellow, entirely red, entirely magenta, entirely black, entirely orange, or entirely beige.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.13_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.1_0: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six wore entirely blue sandals,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.8_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.9_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals with blue straps,
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.2_0: yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, and beige straps.
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.3_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.4_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.5_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6_0: “You should not wear sandals with blue straps,
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6_1: yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, or beige straps.
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals containing leather,
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1_1: enclosing the shin and the foot, enclosing the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having straps fastened with ram-horn, having straps fastened with goat-horn, having straps like scorpion claws, sewn with thread like a peacock’s tail-feather, and decorated in various ways.
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.5_0: “You should not wear sandals containing leather,
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.6_0: enclosing the shin and the foot, enclosing the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having straps fastened with ram-horn, having straps fastened with goat-horn, having straps like scorpion claws, sewn with thread like a peacock’s tail-feather, or decorated in various ways.
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals decorated with lion-skin,
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.1_1: tiger-skin, leopard-skin, deer-skin, otter-skin, cat-skin, squirrel-skin, and bat-skin.
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.5_0: “You should not wear sandals decorated with lion-skin,
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.6_0: tiger-skin, leopard-skin, deer-skin, otter-skin, cat-skin, squirrel-skin, or bat-skin.
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.0_0: The allowance for second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.1_0: After robing up one morning, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and entered Rājagaha for almsfood together with an attendant monk.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.2_0: As he was following behind the Buddha, that monk was limping.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.3_0: A certain lay follower wearing sandals with multi-layered soles saw the Buddha coming.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4_0: He removed his sandals, approached the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4_1: He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.5_0: He then bowed to the attendant monk and asked him,
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.4_0: “Thanks, but the Buddha has prohibited sandals with multi-layered soles.”
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.6_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.7_0: “I allow second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles.
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.8_0: But you should not wear new sandals with multi-layered soles.
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.0_0: The prohibition against sandals inside a monastery.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.1_0: On one occasion the Buddha walked up and down outside without sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.2_0: he walked up and down with sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.3_0: and they walked up and down with sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.4_0: but not the monks from the group of six.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.5_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.6_0: “How can the monks from the group of six walk up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without?”
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.1_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.2_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.5_0: “... How can those foolish men walk up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without?
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.6_0: Even the householders who wear white are respectful and deferential toward their teachers for teaching them the profession by which they make a living.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.1_0: But you who have gone forth on such a well-proclaimed spiritual path will become notorious if you are not respectful and deferential toward your teachers, your preceptors, or those of an equivalent standing.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.2_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.4_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.5_0: “You should not walk up and down with sandals when your teachers, your preceptors, or those of equivalent standing do it without.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.7_0: And you should not wear sandals within a monastery.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:5.1.1_0: Soon afterwards a certain monk was afflicted with corns on his feet.
pli-tv-kd5:5.1.2_0: The monks defecated, urinated, and urinated on the urinal.
pli-tv-kd5:5.1.3_0: Just then the Buddha was walking about the dwellings and he saw this. He then approached those monks and said to them,
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.2_0: “He has corns on his feet, Sir.
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.3_0: but only to defecate, urinate, and spit out of this particular.”
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.4_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.5_0: “I allow you to wear sandals if your feet are painful or cracked, or you have corns on your feet.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.1_0: The monks used beds and benches with dirty feet.
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.2_0: Their robes and the furniture became dirty.
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.4_0: “When you know that you are about to use a bed or bench, I allow you to wear sandals.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.2.1_0: When monks were going to the observance hall or a meeting in the dark of night, they stepped on stumps and thorns, hurting their feet.
pli-tv-kd5:6.2.1_1: and as a result their feet hurt.
pli-tv-kd5:6.2.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:6.2.3_0: “I allow you to wear sandals within a monastery, and also to use a torch, a lamp, and a walking stick.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.0_0: The prohibition against wooden shoes, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.1_0: At one time the monks from the group of six got up early in the morning, put on wooden shoes, and walked up and down outside. They made a loud clacking noise. And they talked about all sorts of pointless things:
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.2_0: about kings, gangsters, and officials; about armies, dangers, and battles; about food, drink, clothes, and beds; about garlands and perfumes; about relatives, vehicles, villages, towns, and countries; about women and heroes; gossip; about the departed; about various trivialities; about the world and the sea; about being this or that.
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.3_0: They stepped on and killed insects, and they roused the monks from the stillness of meditation.
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.11_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.13_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.1_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.2_0: “How can the monks from the group of six act like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.3_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.4_0: They stepped on and killed insects, and they’ll step forwards on the immersion. Such monks will not decline.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.5_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.6_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.7_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.8_0: They stepped on and killed insects, and they roused the monks from the stillness of meditation?”
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.11_0: But not soulling the Sakyan ascetics treading the same thing.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.1_0: After staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Benares.
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.2_0: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Benares,
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.3_0: he stayed in the deer park at Isipattana.
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.4_0: When the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.5_0: the Buddha had prohibited wooden shoes,
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.6_0: they had cuttings made from young palm trees and wore shoes made of palm leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.8_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.9_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.10_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.12_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.13_0: “You should not wear shoes made of palm leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.14_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.1_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.2_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.3_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.7_0: “... How can those foolish men have cuttings made from young palm trees and wear shoes made of palm leaves,
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.10_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.12_0: You should not wear shoes made of bamboo leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.13_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.1_0: When the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.2_0: the Buddha had prohibited shoes made of palm leaves,
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.3_0: the monks from the group of six had cuttings made from young bamboo plants and wore shoes made of bamboo leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.5_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.6_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.8_0: But not soulling the Sakyan ascetics treading the same thing.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.9_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
pli-tv-kd5:8.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Benares for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Bhaddiya.
pli-tv-kd5:8.1.3_0: and stayed in the Jātiyā Grove with Bhaddiya.
pli-tv-kd5:8.1.4_0: At that time the monks in Bhaddiya were fond of various kinds of nice shoes. They made shoes of grass, fishtail-palm leaves, and wool, and they had them made. As a consequence, they neglected recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.1_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.2_0: “How can the monks in Bhaddiya do this?”
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.3_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.4_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks in Bhaddiya do this?”
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.5_0: and neglect recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?”
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.8_0: “... How can those foolish men be fond of various kinds of nice shoes ...
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.9_0: and neglect recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.1_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.3_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.4_0: “You should not wear shoes made of grass, reed, fishtail-palm leaves, or wool; or shoes made with gold, silver, gems, beryl, crystal, bronze, glass, tin, lead, or copper.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.5_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.6_0: And you should not use shoes for walking.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.8_0: I allow three kinds of shoes for shoes: a regular monk is permanent, afflicted, and a safe place.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.9_0: foot-stands for defecating, foot-stands for urinating, foot-stands for restroom rinsing.”
pli-tv-kd5:9.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Bhaddiya for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd5:9.1.3_0: where he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.
pli-tv-kd5:9.1.4_0: At this time, when cattle were crossing the Aciravatī river, the monks from the group of six would grab them by the horns, the ears, the neck, and the tail, and they mounted their backs, and motivated by lust, they touched their genitals. They even killed a calf by submerging it.
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.1_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.2_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.3_0: “... They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.4_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.5_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.3_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.4_0: “You should not grab cattle by the horns, the ears, the neck, or the tail, and you should not mount their backs.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.5_0: If you do mount their backs, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.6_0: And you should not touch their genitals motivated by lust.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.7_0: If you do, you commit a serious offense.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.8_0: And you should not kill a calf.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.9_0: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six traveled in vehicles, sometimes pulled by women with men inside, at other times pulled by men with women inside.
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.3_0: “It’s as if they’re at the Ganges festival.”
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.5_0: “You should not travel in a vehicle.
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
